review.title: Classification of Human Ventricular Arrhythmia in High Dimensional Representation Spaces
review.abstract: We studied classification of human ECGs labelled as normal sinus rhythm, ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia by means of support vector machines in different representation spaces, using different observation lengths. ECG waveform segments of duration 0.5-4 s, their Fourier magnitude spectra, and lower dimensional projections of Fourier magnitude spectra were used for classification. All considered representations were of much higher dimension than in published studies. Classification accuracy improved with segment duration up to 2 s, with 4 s providing little improvement. We found that it is possible to discriminate between ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation by the present approach with much shorter runs of ECG (2 s, minimum 86% sensitivity per class) than previously imagined. Ensembles of classifiers acting on 1 s segments taken over 5 s observation windows gave best results, with sensitivities of detection for all classes exceeding 93%.

sections.heading: II. GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS
sections.text: In view of an ECG segment x = {x [n], n1 ≤ n ≤ n2}, it is desirable to be able to call it SR, VT or VF. For comparison, the presentation of phase space characteristics proposed in [13] is considered in this paper, as the authors conducted a thorough investigation and demonstrated their superior performance in terms of accuracy and numerical complexity compared to previously published algorithms.

sections.heading: A. Reference prior art
sections.text: The Phase Space Algorithm (PSA) [13] aims to diagnose whether a defibrillation shock should be administered, which is equivalent to classifying ECG segments as AF or not. Phase representation is formed by taking discretized values from samples of x as pairs (x1 [n], x2 [n]) in R2, selecting Ex1 [n] = x [n] x2 [n − k] while k is selected to correspond to 0.5 s1. The discretization step is chosen so that the entire range of x1 [n] and x2 [n] each reaches up to 401 unique values. The number N (x) of boxes visited in this phase space is then found, and finally the ratio (x) (x) to N (x).

sections.heading: B. Observation length
sections.text: One of the important questions that needs to be investigated is the appropriate observation length for a reliable classification of cardiac arrhythmias. Longer windows contain more information, and this should lead to a higher classification accuracy, to the point where an increasing observation length does not provide additional discriminatory information. However, this plateau may be followed by a decrease in classification accuracy if the windows are long enough to include transitions between ECG classes. For a quick and reliable diagnosis, it is of interest to simultaneously minimize the observation length and maximize classification accuracy. However, a systematic investigation of this problem is lacking in previous studies. The phase space method in its original formulation counts the number of boxes visited over 8 s segments of ECG signals. Several other studies also form their respective feature vectors using 8 s observations [12], 6 s observations [9], or over 5 s observations.

sections.heading: C. Dimension reduction
sections.text: In order to avoid any distortion due to prejudice about which characteristics are relevant for arrhythmia classification, classification is considered as a starting point directly in the range of ECG waveforms. Furthermore, Fourier size spectra of ECG segments are taken into account as they provide time-changing representations, while most of the information contained in the original waveforms is preserved. At 100 Hz sampling, which is close to the minimum sampling frequency, which does not cause obvious distortions of ECG signals, the 4 s observation length results in a 400-dimensional feature space (or 200-dimensional space when size spectra are taken into account), which can complicate statistical conclusions. This is resolved by using data-driven dimension reduction based on PCA. We conducted PCA based on size spectra of each individual class and formed groups of base vectors by merging the top components of each main class, since each upper class requires at least 5% of energy for each upper class.

sections.heading: III. CLASSIFICATION USING SUPPORT VECTOR MACHINES
sections.text: Faced with a set of training data (x1,.., xp) with corresponding class names (y1,. |., yp), an SVM tries to find a decision interface that collectively maximizes the distance between the two classes and minimizes the misclassification error on the training set. If the classes are linearly separable, these surfaces are linear and have the shape f (x) = ∑ iaiyi < x, xi > + b = 0, ai R + (1), where < ·, · > is the inner product in Rn, while the lagrange multipliers ai and bias b are optimized by the training algorithm. Non-linear separators between two classes are generated using non-linear core functions K (·, ·), where the radial function K (·, ·) is faulty. These functions calculate inner products in 4 higher dimensional spaces without explicitly performing the mapping.

sections.heading: A. Optimising SVM parameters
sections.text: The idea is to avoid the selection of parameters that are too finely tuned to the training data, while still giving good classification performance on invisible examples (test data). sections.heading: C. Classifier ensembles
sections.text: Ensembles or committees of classifiers can often be combined to improve classification accuracy [18]. To this end, we looked at ensembles of decision values of binary SVM classifiers applied to ECG segments of a certain length, with values changing incrementally to each other, e.g. 2 s segments taken over 4 s intervals with 0.5 s layers to form ensembles of 5 decision values, and the mean of the decision values was then used as the corresponding value of fn (x) in the loss decoding according to (9).

sections.heading: B. SVM classification results and comparison with QDA
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: A systematic study of the classification of the ECG rhythm was presented to develop methods for the precise classification between SR, VT and VF. Classification took place in the space of ECG waveforms, their size spectra and low-dimensional approximations of size spectra using projections onto their main component spaces. All display spaces are considered to be of much larger dimensions than in previous studies. We found that classification accuracy improves with an observation length of up to about 2 s, reaching a plateau that is significantly shorter than in previous studies [9], [12], [13]. Since AF can be very short-lived in some animal models, this can support translational research.Among the considered display spaces and classification methods, magnetic spectra and SVM classifiers with RBF nuclei achieved the highest accuracy. Combined, they achieved the classification accuracy of 91% and the sensitivity of at least 86% of the EG2 for each segment of use only.

referenceMentions.context: ACCORDING to the World Health Organisation data, cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death in middle and high income countries, and among the top ten causes of death in low income countries [1].

However, it is evident that although unequivocal ventricular fibrillation (VF), sustained and lethal, is incontestable in electrocardiogram (ECG) recordings, clinicians differ fundamentally about the diagnosis and appellation of transient polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias, with experts in a landmark report unable to agree on whether VF, polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) or torsade de pointes (TDP) best described a range of human tachyarrhythmias in a blinded test of ECG records [2].

Given that mechanisms of these tachyarrhythmias may differ [3] and responses to drugs may vary from benefit to proarrhythmia, depending on the type [4], errors in diagnosis due to unequivocal appellations are potentially hazardous.

Given that mechanisms of these tachyarrhythmias may differ [3] and responses to drugs may vary from benefit to proarrhythmia, depending on the type [4], errors in diagnosis due to unequivocal appellations are potentially hazardous.

To allow preclinical research to be translatable, a definition was recently proposed to discriminate between VF, including brief and transient VF, and other polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias [5].
sequence, and then performs a sequential hypothesis test on the average number of zero crossings until a decision is made [6].

In [7], the authors proposed an algorithm which uses the energy distribution information in a wavelet transform domain to differentiate between VF, VT, and a VT-VF class which contains realisations that are difficult to categorise as either VT or VF.
On the other hand, an estimate of the area occupied in the bispectral representation is proposed for classification between VF, VT, SR and atrial fibrillation in [8].
The standard deviations of the peak amplitudes and peak distances in a cross correlation between a window of ECG and a short window immediately prior is used to classify VT from VF in [9].

An algorithm for VF detection based on empirical mode decomposition (EMD), which creates a lower dimensional representation of ECG waveforms based on the energy in the first EMD component and its spectral entropy, was proposed in [10].
Counting the time between ECG turning points was proposed [11] to differentiate fast-VT, slow-VT and VF for use in automatic implantable cardiovertor defibrillators (AICDs).
non-VF and VF, for use in an automated external defibrillator (AED), was presented in [12].

As in our previous study [14], all ECG records were normalised so that the squared sum of each record is equal to the number of samples in the record, thus making the variance of individual time samples equal to 1.
This classification experiment was performed using 2 s observation windows, as our preliminary work showed that there is minor benefit in using longer segments [14].

metadata.abstractText: We studied classification of human ECGs labelled as normal sinus rhythm, ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia by means of support vector machines in different representation spaces, using different observation lengths. ECG waveform segments of duration 0.5-4 s, their Fourier magnitude spectra, and lower dimensional projections of Fourier magnitude spectra were used for classification. All considered representations were of much higher dimension than in published studies. Classification accuracy improved with segment duration up to 2 s, with 4 s providing little improvement.We found that it is possible to discriminate between ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation by the present approach with much shorter runs of ECG (2 s, minimum 86% sensitivity per class) than previously imagined. Ensembles of classifiers acting on 1 s segments taken over 5 s observation windows gave best results, with sensitivities of detection for all classes exceeding 93%.
